definition:
*Definition.* The $[x,d]_n$ is defined for any number
$x \in \mathbb{C}$, any stepsize $d \in \mathbb{C}$ and any
$n \in \mathbb{Z}$, except for $-x \in \{ d,2d,\dots,nd \}$, by
$$\begin{aligned}
\displaystyle [x,d]_n := \begin{cases} \prod_{j=0}^{n-1}(x-jd) & n \in \mathbb{N}\\
1 & n = 0 \\
\prod_{j=1}^{-n}\frac{1}{x+jd} & -n \in \mathbb{N}, -x \notin \{ d,2d,\dots,nd \}.
\end{cases}\end{aligned}$$

If $x = n$, $d = 1$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$ then
$$\displaystyle [n,1]_n = \begin{cases} n(n-1)\dots(2)(1) & n > 0 \\
1 & n = 0, \end{cases}$$ on which it follows that $[n,1]_n = n!$. This
is why the above definition generalizes the notion of the usual
factorial.
